title: Maitland celebrates multiculturalism on Australia Day | Gloucester Advocate
body_text:
Hazara refugee from Afghanistan Asif Sultani came to Maitland at age 16, with only a few belongings in a rubbish bag, and couldn't speak English.

He took to the stage at Maitland's Australia Day ceremony to affirm to the city's 21 newly inducted citizens that multiculturalism is a strength.
Mr Sultani, who was made an Australian citizen in December, shared his story of hope, and encouraged all new citizens to give back to the community that helped him get on his feet.
"I'm sure that lots of you here today have also been supported in incredible ways by the Maitland community, and I encourage you to share stories, to continue to connect with the locals," he said.
"Multiculturalism is a strength and there's so much we can all learn from one another."
There were many moments of joy, hope and appreciation for the community shared at Maitland's Australia Day ceremony.
Not only were 21 new citizens welcomed to Australia and to Maitland, but a deserving group of residents were awarded Maitland City Council Australia Day awards.
Citizen of the Year
Former teacher, committed Rotarian and Maitland HealthStays chair Trevor Lynch was named Maitland's Citizen of the Year.
Nominator Suzanne Morgan said Mr Lynch embodies Rotary's motto of 'service above self', and his commitment to the community has impacted countless lives.
In recent years, Mr Lynch's focus has been on getting Maitland HealthStays off the ground.
The project will see affordable accommodation for people travelling to Maitland to receive health treatment built close to Maitland Hospital.
Land has been purchased in Metford and a development application is currently with Maitland City Council.
Mr Lynch said is humbled, honoured and more than shocked to receive the honour.
"This particular award, this Citizen of the Year really isn't for me, it's for the team of people who come together to do this," he said.
"I'll finish with an anonymous comment: when you give your time, you plant seeds of kindness that grow far beyond what you can see."
Young Citizen of the Year
All-abilities sporting coach and psychology research assistant Meg Jackson, 25, was named Maitland's Young Citizen of the Year.
Ms Jackson has a passion for all-abilities sport and has made significant contributions to local clubs in netball and touch football.
As an assistant coach for all-abilities teams, Meg advocates for inclusivity and positive experiences for young players. Meg's passion also extends beyond the field.
As a research assistant with a First Class Honours in Psychology, Meg has dedicated countless hours to researching the impact of child sports anxiety with the hopes of contributing to future policy and making a difference in the lives of others.
Deserving award winners
Young Thornton hero Luke Mullard, 13, who bravely saved 92-year-old Roma Wilson from a house fire in November 2025 was recognised with a special award for his bravery. Ms Wilson was in attendance to cheer him on.
Rotary Club of East Maitland member Carol Coffey won the City of Maitland Service Award for her dedicated volunteer work throughout the community.
Maitland Patchwork Quilters won the City of Maitland Medal in recognition of its support for those experiencing homelessness.
Star softball player Arwen Kavanagh was named Sportsperson of the Year for her exceptional success playing softball at a club, state, national and international level including representing Australia's under 18s women's team at the World Cup qualifiers in Texas in 2025.
Maitland Musical Theatre member Alcyon Manen was named Creative Arts Person of the Year for her outstanding service to Maitland's musical theatre scene. She wears many hats including performer, set designer, choreographer and director.
